sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of accident occurring in a workplace
message_1: A factory has 50 machines and each has a 1% chance of malfunctioning on any given day. What is the probability that exactly 2 machines will malfunction on a single day?
message_2:
We can solve this problem using the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(X = k) = (nCk) * (p^k) * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, k = 2 malfunctions)
- n is the number of trials (in this case, n = 50 machines)
- nCk is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (50C2 in this case)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, p = 0.01, the probability of a machine malfunctioning)
- 1-p is the probability of failure (in this case, 1-0.01 = 0.99, the probability of a machine not malfunctioning)

Plugging in the values, we get:

P(X = 2) = (50C2) * (0.01^2) * (0.99^48)

First, we calculate 50C2:

50C2 = 50! / (2! * (50-2)!)
50C2 = 50! / (2! * 48!)
50C2 = (50 * 49) / (2 * 1) = 1225

Now, we plug this value back into the probability formula:

P(X = 2) = 1225 * (0.01^2) * (0.99^48)

Calculating the probabilities:

0.01^2 = 0.0001
0.99^48 ≈ 0.605006

Now, we multiply all the values together:

P(X = 2) = 1225 * 0.0001 * 0.605006
P(X = 2) ≈ 0.0741

So, the probability that exactly 2 machines will malfunction on a single day is approximately 7.41%.
